europeana:record.dc:title: Instruction on the life of purity modelled on the lives of saints
De institutione benevivendi(!) per exempla sanctorum
europeana:record.dc:creator: Marulić, Marko
europeana:record.dc:subject: 240 Christian moral & devotional theology
europeana:record.dc:description: De institutione Bene Vivendi per Exempla Sanctorum (Instruction on the Life of Purity Modelled on the Lives of Saints) is one of poet, Marko Marulić's most translated works. Published in 1506, it is just one of the many books that went towards establishing him as a world author. Although he wrote and published many works in Latin, his books were translated in to many European languages. This particular work comprises a collection of six volumes covering the lives of saints, and their moral teachings. Some editions of the book include the poem 'Carmen de Doctrina D. N. Iesu Christi Pendentis in Cruce (Poem on the Word of our Lord Jesus Christ Crucified), which was also translated into many languages in the 16th and the 17th centuries.

Marko Marulić (1450.–1524.) napisao je i objavio mnoga djela na latinskom jeziku te po njima postao svjetskim piscem, ne samo zato što su mu djela tiskana po cijeloj Europi, nego i stoga što su prevedena na mnoge europske jezike. Među najviše prevođenim knjigama jest De institutione bene vivendi per exempla sanctorum (Uputa u blažen život po primjerima svetaca)iz 1506. To je zbirka od šest knjiga u kojima su ispričani mnogobrojni događaji iz života svetaca i pouke što se iz njih trebaju izvući. U nekim je izdanjima toj knjizi priključena pjesma Carmen de doctrina D. N. Jesu Christi pendentis in cruce (Pjesma o nauku Gospodina našega Isusa Krista koji visi na križu), koja je u XVI. i XVII. st. bila prevedena na mnoge jezike.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Venetiis, presbiter Franciscus Lucensis de Consortibus et Bernardinus de Vitalibus
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Osman
Osman : spievagnie ... Giva Frana Gundulichia
europeana:record.dc:creator: Gundulić, Ivan
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages;090 Manuscripts & rare books
europeana:record.dc:description: This poem is hailed as one of the greatest works of early Croation literature. It recounts the life of Sultan Osman II in twenty cantos. The historical and romantic epic follows Osman's life from his violent seizure of power, the defeat of the Turkish army at the battle of Chocim in 1621, the Janissary revolt, through to his dethroning and execution in Constantinople. Gundulić's poetic account highlights the punishment of pride, establishment of justice and decline of power, at this pivotal point in the history of the Ottoman empire. With two missing cantos at its heart, several attempts have already been made to complete the account. The poem is currently reprinted with additions by Ivan Mažuranić from the 1844 Matica hrvatska edition.

Osman je povijesno-romantični ep u dvadeset pjevanja, kojemu nedostaju četrnaesto i petnaesto. Više je puta dopjevavan, a danas se tiska s dopunama Ivana Mažuranića iz Matičina izdanja 1844. Ep opisuje nasilni dolazak na vlast sultana Osmana II. i poraz turske vojske 1621. kod Hoćima u Poljskoj, pobunu janjičara i svrgnuće Osmana s prijestolja te njegovo ubojstvo u Carigradu. Tim je događajima Gundulić dao značenje kažnjavanja oholosti, uspostavljanja pravde i početak rasapa turske sile te svega zla s njom povezanoga. Gundulić je najuspješniju onodobno svjetsko pjesništvo (Tasso) uspješno presadio na domaće tlo i napisao jedno od najboljih djela starije hrvatske književnosti.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: The Roman Missal in Glagolitic script
Misal po zakonu rimskoga dvora
europeana:record.dc:subject: 090 Manuscripts & rare books;200 Religion
europeana:record.dc:description: The 'Misal Prema Zakonu Rimskoga Dvora' is the oldest Croatian printed book, dating back to 1483. As well as being the oldest, it is also the first European missal not printed in the Latin language. Although its place of publication is not known, it's believed it was either in Venice or Kosinj. Its printing coincided with the celebration of the throne of St. Peter, as a display of loyalty to the Catholic Church by the Glagolitic monks. The printing of the book marked the pinnacle of Croation Glagolitic activity and the beginning of its decline. Unfortunately, the Glagolitic scribes would not be able to compete with the advent of the printing press. Eleven copies have survived, six of which are in Croatia with the rest abroad.

Misal po zakonu Rimskoga dvora iz 1483. najstarija je hrvatska tiskana knjiga i prvi europski misal koji nije tiskan latinskim jezikom i latiničnim pismom. U kolofonu nema podataka o mjestu tiskanja, pa su se u raspravama spominjala različita mjesta, najčešće Mletci i Kosinj. Kao tekstovni predložak poslužilo je nekoliko pisanih hrvatskoglagoljskih misala, posebno Misal kneza Novaka (1368.). Tiskanje je završeno na dan kada se slavi prijestolje svetoga Petra apostola; glagoljaši su i tim činom htjeli pokazati vjernost Rimskoj crkvi. Tiskanje te knjige vrhunac je rasta hrvatskoga glagoljaštva i ujedno početak nazadovanja: glagoljaši neće moći pratiti brzi razvitak koji je nametnula pojava tiska. Sačuvano je jedanaest primjeraka, šest u Hrvatskoj i pet u inozemstvu.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Hymns of Repentance
გალობანი სინანულისანი
europeana:record.dc:creator: David the Builder
europeana:record.dc:description: David the Builder, popularly considered to be the greatest and most successful Georgian ruler in history, composed, c. 1120, "Hymns of Repentance", a sequence of eight free-verse psalms, with each hymn having its own intricate and subtle stanza form. For all their Christianity, cult of the Mother of God, and the king’s emotional repentance of his sins, David sees himself as reincarnating the Biblical David, with a similar relationship to God and to his people. His hymns also share the idealistic zeal of the contemporaneous European crusaders to whom David was a natural ally in his struggle against the Seljuks.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Masnavi
Mesnevi
europeana:record.dc:creator: Mevlana Celaleddin Rumi
europeana:record.dc:subject: 090 Manuscripts & rare books
europeana:record.dc:description:
It was copied in Herat in the 18th century. It was written with a exquisite calligraphy on silk paper. Rosette of the lacquered binding has the icon of Mary and Jesus Chirist.
This famous work is six volumes. THe headings of the first two of each volume azure gilded.

18. yüzyılda, Herat’ta istinsah edilmiştir. Nefis bir hatla ipek kâğıda yazılmıştır. Lake cilt içerisinde olup şemsesinde Hz. Meryem ile oğlu Hz. İsa’nın ikonu vardır. Eserin tamamı olan altı cilt bir aradadır. Her cildin ilk iki sayfa serlevhası laciverdi müzehheptir.

europeana:record.dc:title: Elegy
Élégie
europeana:record.dc:creator: La Fontaine, Jean de (1621-1695)
europeana:record.dc:subject: France -- 1643-1715 (Louis XIV)
europeana:record.dc:description: "He is under arrest, and the king is so worked up he says he has the evidence necessary to get him hanged. Ah! If he does, he will be even crueller than his enemies," La Fontaine said when he told his friend Maucroix about the fate of their protector, superintendant of finances Nicolas Fouquet (1615-1680), who was arrested on 5 September 1661 shortly after a lavish reception at his château in Vaux-le-Vicomte to which he had invited Louis XIV. La Fontaine (1621-1695) soon tried to ward off the king’s cruelty with his Élégie aux Nymphes de Vaux, an appeal to royal clemency where lament drowns out the echo of the “Songe de Vaux” (“Vaux Dream”) féerie galante on which he had been working since 1659. Only three copies of the original edition of the Élégie, which was written anonymously and secretly printed around March 1662, are extant. It was attributed to Paul Pellisson, another Fouquet protégé, until La Fontaine acknowledged authorship in 1671. Although imprisoned in the Bastille, Pellisson had published the Discours au roi, which also beseeched the king for mercy. It was in prose, so La Fontaine’s verses were its poetic counterpart. "You know the interest Le Parnasse takes in everything that affects you," La Fontaine told Fouquet in January 1663.

" Il est arrêté, et le roi est violent contre lui, au point qu’il dit avoir entre les mains des pièces qui le feront pendre. Ah ! s’il le fait, il sera autrement cruel que ses ennemis " : La Fontaine apprenait ainsi à son ami Maucroix le sort de leur protecteur, le surintendant des Finances Nicolas Fouquet (1615-1680), arrêté le 5 septembre 1661 peu après la réception fastueuse à laquelle il avait convié Louis XIV dans son château de Vaux-le-Vicomte. C’est cette cruauté royale que La Fontaine (1621-1695) tente bientôt de prévenir par les vers de son Élégie aux Nymphes de Vaux, appel à la clémence princière où se perçoit, assourdi dans la plainte, l’écho de la féerie galante du Songe de Vaux à laquelle il travaillait depuis 1659. L’anonymat de l’édition originale de l’Élégie, imprimée clandestinement vers mars 1662, dont on ne conserve aujourd'hui que trois exemplaires, et que La Fontaine ne reconnut qu'en 1671, favorisa longtemps une attribution à Paul Pellisson, autre protégé de Fouquet. Bien qu’embastillé, Pellisson avait publié un Discours au roi appelant aussi à la clémence, morceau de prose oratoire auquel les vers de La Fontaine font un pendant poétique. Le poète pouvait à juste titre déclarer à Fouquet, en janvier 1663 : " Vous savez quel intérêt le Parnasse prend à ce qui vous touche. ".

europeana:record.dc:title: Arsena Marabdeli
არსენა მარაბდელი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Javakhishvili, Mikheil
europeana:record.dc:description: Mikheil Javakhishvili (November 8, 1880 – September 30, 1937) was a Georgian novelist who is regarded as one of the top twentieth-century Georgian writers. His first story appeared in 1903, but then the writer lapsed into a long pause before returning to writing in the early 1920s. His recalcitrance to the Soviet ideological pressure cost him life: he was executed during Stalin's Great Purge and his writings were banned for nearly twenty years. In the words of the modern British scholar of Russian and Georgian literature, Donald Rayfield, "his vivid story-telling, straight in medias res, his buoyant humour, subtle irony, and moral courage merit comparison with those of Stendhal, Maupassant, and Zola. In modern Georgian prose only Konstantine Gamsakhurdia could aspire to the same international level." The crowning merit of Javakhishvili’s work – the novel Arsena Marabdeli – was composed between 1933 and 1936. The writer spent years on research and rewriting a Russian as well as a Georgian version of the novel. The plot is based on the life of a real historical figure, the brigand Arsena, who is also a favorite hero of Georgian folklore. Javakhishvili focuses on the tragic necessity that makes the chivalrous peasant Arsena to degenerate into the typical 19th-century bandit. Although the story of an outlaw fighting against the gentry was considered "ideologically correct", the "left" critics were suspicious of Javakhishvili’s recognizable parallels between Imperial Russia and the Soviet state. Javakhishvili put many of his thoughts into Arsena’s mouth. One example is his famous phrase: "Russia is galloping after Europe and the bleeding body it is dragging after it on a rope is Georgia". The work won great popularity from the common reader and bitter attacks from the Communist critics and proletarian writers who accused him of corruption, misrepresentation, slander, and subversion.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: The Misfortunes of Darispan
დარისპანის გასაჭირი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Kldiashvili, Davit
europeana:record.dc:description: David Kldiashvili (August 29, 1862 – April 24, 1931) was a Georgian prose-writer whose novels and plays are concentrated on the degeneration of the country’s gentry and the miseries of the peasantry, boldly exposing the antagonisms of Georgian society. The novel The Misfortunes of Darispan is typically tragicomic impregnated with what the author himself referred to as "tears mixed with a smile".
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Abdulmesiani
აბდულმესიანი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Shavteli, Ioane
europeana:record.dc:description: Ioane Shavteli was a Georgian poet of the late 12th and early 13th centuries credited to have written the encomiastic poem traditionally, and unsuitably, known as Abdulmesia, i.e., "Slave of the Messiah" (from Arabic Abdul Masīh). Shavteli's panegyric focuses on praising the Christian virtues of David the Builder and Queen Tamar, without naming either, however. The references to Tamar are coded by praise of her beauty, her love of "doing good by stealth", also praised in similar phrases by the queen's chronicler as well as by the two contemporary poets - Rustaveli and Chakhrukhadze. David can be recognized by allusions to his biblical namesake (from whom the Georgian dynasty of Bagrationi claimed descent) as well as by interweaving words and phrases from the king’s own religious lyrics, the Hymns of Repentance.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Eleanor's victory : Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Braddon, Mary Elizabeth
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Novelist Mary Elizabeth Braddon's (1835-1915) sensational ‘bigamy’ novel, ‘Lady Audley’s Secret’ (1862) proved a resounding success and saw her labelled as the queen of the circulating libraries. She was a rebelious force in Victorian England and her relationship with 'penny dreadful' publisher John Maxwell scandalised society at the time. Having taken up writing to escape poverty, at her peak she was earning around £2000 a novel. She published over 80 novels with unusually feisty heroine's for the time. Her leading lady in ‘Eleanor’s Victory’ (1863) even gains revenge for her father’s murder.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Martyrdom of Abo Tbileli
წამებაჲ წმიდისა და ნეტარისა მოწამისა ქრისტჱსისა ჰაბოჲსი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Sabanisdze, Ioane
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Church Museum of the Exarchate of Georgia
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Tamariani (A Hymn to Queen Tamar)
თამარიანი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Chakhrukhadze
europeana:record.dc:description: Chakhrukhadze is a Georgian poet of the late 12th/early 13th century traditionally credited to have written Tamariani, a collection of twenty-two odes and one elegy praising, often deifying Queen Tamar of Georgia. The poet is identified with the certain layman Grigol Chakhrukhadze whose survived testament unveils the author's desire to retire to the Georgian Monastery of the Holy Cross at Jerusalem. Based upon a new, pentasyllabic, verse-form (chakhrukhauli), Chakhrukhadze's poetry is remarkable for musicality and linguistic virtuosity, using masterly rhymed adjectives to eulogize Tamar.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Dantons Tod
europeana:record.dc:creator: Büchner, Georg
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages

europeana:record.dc:title: Swiss military parody
Eines Schwitzerischen Casperals Exercitium
europeana:record.dc:subject: Military science
europeana:record.dc:description: A parody written in dialect, of which only one other copy is known
Parodie en dialecte dont on ne connaît qu'un seul autre exemplaire

europeana:record.dc:title: Die Marquise von O
europeana:record.dc:creator: Kleist, Heinrich von
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:title: Lecture on the anatomy of the brain
Discours de M. Stenon sur l'anatomie du cerveau
europeana:record.dc:creator: Steensen, Niels (1638-1686)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Cerveau -- Anatomie
europeana:record.dc:description: In 1664 Niels Stensen, known in French as Sténon (1638-1686), moved from Denmark to Paris, attending gatherings of mathematicians, physicists, astronomers and other learned men at the home of his host, Melchisédech Thévenot, where the Academy of Sciences came into existence in 1666. It is also where Stensen delivered his 1665 Discours sur l’anatomie du cerveau (“lecture on the anatomy of the brain”), published four years later. Reacting to some of Descartes’ ideas in his 1662 Treatise on Man, the Danish anatomist argued that everything known about the brain had to be forgotten until the organ was painstakingly dissected, which he promptly set out to do. The plates’ quality attests to his powers of observation. Stensen’s little book was not only a major breakthrough in knowledge about the brain, but also one of the best illustrations of the 17th century’s new scientific spirit.

Arrivé à Paris en 1664 et hébergé par Melchisédech Thévenot, le Danois Niels Stensen, dit Sténon (1638-1686), participa naturellement aux assemblées de savants qui se tenaient régulièrement chez son hôte, d’où naquit en 1666 l’Académie des sciences. C’est là qu’il prononça en 1665 son Discours sur l’anatomie du cerveau, publié quatre ans plus tard. En réagissant à certaines propositions avancées par Descartes dans son traité de L’Homme de 1662, il appelait à renoncer à toute interprétation des fonctions du cerveau avant d’avoir minutieusement disséqué la structure anatomique de celui-ci. La qualité des planches qui accompagnent la publication porte d’ailleurs le témoignage de cette exigence d’observation. Ainsi le petit livre de Sténon représente non seulement une avancée majeure dans la connaissance du cerveau, mais aussi une des plus belles illustrations du nouvel esprit scientifique du XVIIe siècle.

europeana:record.dc:title: Latin compendium
Compendium latinum proponens XII posteriores figuras libri observationum necnon priores VII figuras libri organici
europeana:record.dc:creator: Verbiest, Ferdinand (1623-1688)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Qing Shengzu (empereur de Chine ; 1654-1722)
europeana:record.dc:description: In 1669 China’s Emperor Qangxi appointed Ferdinand Verbiest (1623-1688), a Belgian-born Jesuit who joined Père Adam Schall’s team of missionary astronomers in Peking in 1659, president of the mathematics tribunal and ordered him to make new instruments for the Imperial Observatory. The 1678 Compendium latinum is one of the treatises he published to describe their principles and functioning, adding it as a separate chapter to his 1687 Astronomia Europea. In 1684 Père Philippe Couplet, Verbiest’s envoy, may have given Louis XIV the copy on display here, which features a red silk cover with gold brocade Chinese motifs, but that hypothesis remains to be proven

Jésuite d’origine belge venu en 1659 rejoindre à Pékin l’équipe de missionnaires astronomes du Père Adam Schall, Ferdinand Verbiest (1623-1688) fut nommé en 1669 président du tribunal des mathématiques par l’empereur Kangxi et reçut l’ordre de fabriquer de nouveaux instruments pour l’Observatoire impérial. Le Compendium latinum de 1678 est l’un des traités qu’il publia pour décrire le principe et le fonctionnement des instruments créés, avant d’en faire un chapitre particulier de son Astronomia Europea de 1687. Revêtu d’une couverture en soie rouge à motifs chinois brochés d’or, l’exemplaire présenté ici a peut-être été offert à Louis XIV en 1684 par le Père Philippe Couplet, envoyé de Verbiest, mais cette provenance reste de l’ordre de l’hypothèse.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Jungfrau railway : Bernese Oberland (Switzerland) - In French
Chemin de fer de la Jungfrau : Oberland Bernois (Suisse)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Railroad transportation
europeana:record.dc:description: This booklet documents the Jungfrau Railway, which was completed in 1912 with the construction of the station Jungfraujoch (Top of Europe, 3454 metres above sea level)
Cette brochure présente la ligne de chemin de fer de la Jungfrau, terminée en 1912 avec la construction de la gare Jungfraujoch, à 3454 mètre d'altitude
Diese Broschüre dokumentiert die Jungfraubahn, die erst 1912 mit dem Bau der Station Jungfraujoch (Top of Europe, 3454 m. ü. M.) vollendet wurde

europeana:record.dc:title: New machines
Machinae novae Fausti Verantii Siceni cum declaratione Latina Italica Hispanica Gallica et Germanica
europeana:record.dc:creator: Vrančić, Faust
europeana:record.dc:subject: 620 Engineering & allied operations
europeana:record.dc:description: Faust Vrančić (1551–1617) was author of the first independently printed Croatian dictionary before he became fascinated with technical devices. While serving as secretary at the court of the Croatian-Hungarian King and Emperor of Austria, Rudolph II in Vienna, he fell under the influence of a circle of engineers. Their involvement in organising cities and roads inspired him to start exploring devices that would make life easier. When he joined the Barnabites in Rome, he met Giovanni Ambrogaia Mazento, who showed him some of Leonardo da Vinci's drawings and helped him learn about engine design and solving architectural problems. All this encouraged Vrančić to produce his book 'Machinae Novae', containing 59 designs of various appliances and devices. One of its best known images is that of Homo volans (A flying man) – a picture of a man with a 'parachute'.

Faust Vrančić (1551.–1617.), autor prvoga samostalno tiskanoga hrvatskoga rječnika, obnašao je dužnost tajnika na dvoru hrvatsko-ugarskoga kralja i austrijskoga cara Rudolfa II. u Beču. Našao se u krugu tehničara i tehnologa koji su se brinuli o tehničkim problemima organizacije života, uređenja gradova, izgradnje putova i vojnih sprava. Druženje s Jakobom de Stradom, dalo mu je dodatne poticaje da razmišlja o tehničkim napravama koje bi život učinile ljepšim. Kada je stupio u red barnabita u Rimu, upoznao se s Giovannijem Ambrogiom Mazentom koji mu je dao na uvid neke crteže Leonarda da Vincija i pomogao mu da sazna o konstrukciji strojeva i o rješavanju arhitektonskih problema. Sve je to potaknulo Vrančića da u knjizi Machinae novae ponudi rješenja 59 različitih uređaja i naprava koji obogatili tehničku znanost. Među najpoznatijim je slikama Homo volans (leteći čovjek) – slika čovjeka koji leti ”padobranom”.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Black sheep : Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Yates, Edmund Hodgson
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Edmund Yates (1831-94) worked in the missing letters department of the General Post Office. As a journalist he laid claim to inventing the gossip column. His crime story ‘Black Sheep’ (1867) was serialized in Dickens’ ‘All the Year Round’. The hero, George Dallas, is disowned after involvement with the swindler, Stewart Routh. But all ends happily when he is eventually reconciled with his family. It is rumoured that Mrs Cashel Hoey wrote most of the novel.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Wisdom of Lie
სიბრძნე სიცრუისა
europeana:record.dc:creator: Orbeliani, Sulkhan-Saba
europeana:record.dc:description: A well-known Georgian writer, lexicographer and scholar Sulkhan-Saba Orbeliani lived in the 17th century. Besides the collected fables "The Wisdom of Lie" and a memoirs work "A Journey Through Europe", he is the author of the Georgian Dictionary.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: The History of Estonian Folk Costumes
Eesti rahvariiete ajalugu
europeana:record.dc:creator: Ilmari Manninen
europeana:record.dc:subject: Estonian, national costumes, ethnographical museums, ethnology;Estonian, national costumes, ethnographical museums, ethnology
europeana:record.dc:description: The History of Estonian Folk Costumes' was the first comprehensive study of the country's national costumes. Compiled by the director of the Estonian National Museum, Ilmari Manninen, it was published in the third issue of the Museum’s year book in 1927. The author closely examines the traditional attire, drawing attention to the garmets and their historical origins. His approach proved unique and differed from that of later researchers. Due to the rarity of the first edition, a new edition of the study was printed in 2009.

Eesti Rahva Muuseumi direktori Ilmari Mannineni koostatud Eesti rahvariiete ajalugu on avaldatud 1927.aastal muuseumi aastaraamatu kolmandas numbris. See on esimene ulatuslik käsitlus eesti rahvariiete kohta. Autor vaatleb rahvarõivaid analüüsivalt esemeliikide kaupa, tundes huvi ka nende ajaloolise päritolu vastu. Ilmari Mannineni teemakäsitlus on ainulaadne ja ernev hilisemaste uurijate omast. 2009. aastal ilmus Eesti rahvariiete ajaloo kordusväljaanne, sest esmatrükk on muutunud harulduseks.

europeana:record.dc:title: Fate of Georgia
ბედი ქართლისა
europeana:record.dc:creator: Baratashvili, Nikoloz
europeana:record.dc:description: Nikoloz Baratashvili (December 4, 1817 - October 21, 1844) was a Georgian poet, one of the first Georgians to marry a modern nationalism with European Romanticism and to introduce "Europeanism" into Georgian literature. Despite his early death and a tiny literary heritage of fewer than forty short lyrics, one extended poem, and a few private letters, Baratashvili is considered to be the high point of Georgian Romanticism. The poem Fate of Georgia, written by Baratashvili at the age of 22, is based on a real historical event: the 1795 ruining of Tbilisi by the Persian ruler Mohammad Khan Qajar, which forced the disappointed Georgian king Erekle II to relegate his country's security onto the Russian Empire. However, national problems considered in this work are viewed with a modern approach; the poem considers not only Georgia’s past, but also its future in the aftermath of the failed revolt of 1832. In this poem, Baratashvili reproduces the debate of Erekle II with his chancellor, Solomon Lionidze, who opposes the union with Russia and thinks that this will result in the loss of Georgia’s national identity. The sympathies of the poet and reader both fall on Solomon’s side, but the objectively rational decision of the king prevails.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: A Toast, or A Night Feast after War near Yerevan
სადღეგრძელო ანუ ომის შემდგომ ღამე ლხინი, ერევნის სიახლოვეს
europeana:record.dc:creator: Orbeliani, Grigol
europeana:record.dc:description: Grigol Orbeliani's best and longest work is an ode A Toast, or A Night Feast after War near Yerevan, whose original version was composed on the occasion of the battle of Yerevan during the Russo-Persian War in 1827, not without influence of the Russian poet Vasily Zhukovsky. It was further reworked and expanded until it acquired its final shape as late as 1879. A nostalgic memory of military glory, the poem begins by honoring all those who have fallen in defense of their homeland, then the poet travels through history, celebrating all Georgia’s tribes, kings, heroes, and martyrs. Finally, an elegiac mood replaces the exaltation, as the poet returns from his fantasy and memoirs to see just himself and one other link to that past still living.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: The Letter of Marko Marulić to Pope Hadrian VI.
Epistola domini Marci Maruli Spalatensis ad Adrianum VI. pont. max. de calamitatibus occurrentibus et exhortatio ad communem omnium Christianorum unionem et pacem
europeana:record.dc:creator: Marulić, Marko
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages;940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: Marko Marulić (1450 - 1524) sent this missive to Pope Hadrian VI on 5 April 1522, demanding an end to Christian atrocities by Ottoman forces. He appeals to Pope Hadrian to use his reputation to influence the western Christian rulers to unite and crush the Ottoman enemy, whom he compares to predatory, bloodthirsty wolves. The missive ends in a Prayer of Marko Marulić to Christ, for Pope Hadrian VI, in 16 elegiac couplets. Marulić's public communication is one of the most important literary testimonies ever sent to Peter's heir by a Croatian writer and Catholic. Two years after his death, all the events Marulić forewarned the Pope about in his missive, unfolded. The Ottoman forces annihilated the Christian army in the battle of Mohács in 1526 and the Croatian-Hungarian Kingdom was crushed.

Marko Marulić (1450. - 1524.) je 5. travnja 1522. uputio poslanicu papi Hadrijanu VI. U proslovu se obraća učenomu dominikancu Kotoraninu Dominiku Bući (o. 1480.-o. 1560.), koji je od njega zahtijevao da Svetomu Ocu pismenim putem iznese sve patnje kršćanskoga puka što mu ih svakodnevno nanose turski zlotvori. Papu Hadrijana pak moli da svojim ugledom utječe na zapadnokršćanske vladare kako bi prestali s međusobnim razmiricama i ujedinili se u obrani kršćanskoga svijeta te zajednički oduprli neprijatelju, kojega uspoređuje s grabežljivim i krvoločnim vukom. Poslanica završava Molitvom Marka Marulića Kristu za papu Hadrijana VI. u 16 elegijskih dvostihova. Marulićevo otvoreno pismo izuzetno je književno svjedočanstvo što ga je ikada jedan hrvatski književnik i katolički vjernik uputio Petrovu nasljedniku, a dvije godine nakon njegove smrti obistinilo sve ono na što je Papu upozoravao: na Mohaču su 1526. turske horde do nogu porazile kršćansku vojsku i uništile Hrvatsko-ugarsko kraljevstvo.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Tripartitum or Triple Codex
Decretvm Latino-Hungaricum juris consvetudinarij inclyti regni Hungariae et Transylvaniae Az az Magyar és Erdely országnak törvény könyve
europeana:record.dc:creator: Werbőczy István
europeana:record.dc:subject: Történelem;940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: István Werbőczy’s Tripartitum or Triple Codex (Tripartitum opus iuris consuetudinarii inclyti regni Hungariae) was written in 1514, summarising the Hungarian customary law of four centuries, its first edition was published in Vienna (1517). This bilingual edition of Tripartitum was based upon the Debrecen edition of 1611, which was a new and correct translation. The second part after Tripartitum was compiled from Joannes Sambucus’ Vienna edition of 1581.

Werbőczy István Hármaskönyve (Tripartitum opus iuris consuetudinarii inclyti regni Hungariae) 1514-ben íródott, a négy évszázados magyar szokásjog összefoglalását tartalmazza, első alkalommal 1517-ben jelent meg Bécsben. A Tripartitum e kétnyelvű kiadása az 1611-es debreceni editión alapul, amely a korábbinál pontosabb, új fordítást tartalmazott. A Tripartitum után következő részt Zsámboky János (Joannes Sambucus) 1581. évi bécsi kiadásából vették át.

europeana:record.dc:title: A poem of praise to Master Guarini of Verona
Ad Guarinum Veronensem Panegyricus. Eiusdem Elegiarum liber. Et Epigrammatum syluula. Item Lazari Bonamici Carmina nonnulla
europeana:record.dc:creator: Česmički, Ivan
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Ianus Pannonius (1434-1472) is considered the greatest poet of European humanism. His works include many epigrams and elegies, including 'U smrt majke Barbare and Svojoj duši'. Two of his panegyrics proved to be his most famous work – one dedicated to his teacher Guarini, the other to the his Venetian benefactor and friend, Antonio Marcelo. Better known as Ivan Česmički, the poet was elected Bishop of Pecs, but lived mostly at the court of the Croatian - Hungarian king Matthias Corvinus. He later fled to Venice after hatching a plot against the ruler. Pannonius died in the Medvedgrad castle, and was burried in Remete. His remains were later transferred to Pecs cathedral.

Jan Panonije, u starijoj literaturi poznat kao Ivan Česmički (1434.–1472.), humanist, diplomat i pjesnik, školovao se u Ferrari kod Guarina Guarinija, zatim u Padovi. Imenovan je pečuškim biskupom, ali je najviše boravio na dvoru hrvatsko-ugarskoga kralja Matijaša Korvina i pratio ga na vojnim pohodima te odlazio u diplomatska izaslanstva. Zajedno s ujakom Ivanom Vitezom i zagrebačkim biskupom Osvaldom Thuzom organizirao je urotu protiv kralja, a kada je ona otkrivena, Jan u bijegu prema Veneciji umire na Medvedgradu te biva pokopan u Remetama. Kralj Matijaš Korvin naredio je da se njegovo mrtvo tijelo prenese u pečušku biskupsku crkvu. Napisao je mnoge epigrame i elegije od kojih se ističu U smrt majke Barbare i Svojoj duši. Prevodio je s grčkog na latinski. Među panegiricima dva su najpoznatija – jedan je posvetio svojem učitelju Guarinu, drugi meceni, mletačkomu prijatelju Antoniju Marcelu. Djela su mu često tiskana i drži se najvećim pjesnikom europskoga humanizma.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Orthodox ritual book containing prayers
Trebnic
europeana:record.dc:subject: 090 Manuscripts & rare books
europeana:record.dc:description: This document was published at the Chisinau Church printing-house in 1859. The National Library of the Republic of Moldova holds the only two existing copies, both of which are in good condition. The manuscript has been included in the Register of the National Programme “The Memory of Moldova”, section “Patrimonial documents of national importance stored in the territory of Moldova.

În colecţiile patrimoniale ale BNRM se păstrează 2 exemplare unice în ţară ale documentului respectiv, editate în Tipografia Duhovnicească din Chişinău la 1859 cu o stare de conservare bună. Incluse în Registrul Programului Naţional „Memoria Moldovei" (compartimentul „Documente patrimoniale păstrate în teritoriul Republicii Moldova de importanţă naţională").
europeana:record.dc:publisher: National Library of the Republic of Moldova

europeana:record.dc:title: Leonard and Gertrude : a book for the poor Vol. 4
Lienhard und Gertrud : ein Buch für das Volk Vol. 4
europeana:record.dc:creator: Pestalozzi, Johann Heinrich
europeana:record.dc:subject: 370 Education
europeana:record.dc:description: This novel of the countryside by the reforming pedagogue Pestalozzi is about village corruption and the possibility of its removal by enlightened government. The work was a pan-European success
Ce roman paysan du pédagogue réformateur Pestalozzi traite de corruption villageoise et des possibilités de l'éradiquer par l'exercice d'un pouvoir éclairé. L'ouvrage fut un succès européen
Dieser Bauernroman des Reformpädagogen Pestalozzi handelt von dörflicher Korruption und der Möglichkeit ihrer Beseitigung durch eine aufgeklärte Obrigkeit. Das Werk war ein europaweiter Erfolg

europeana:record.dc:title: A dictionary of the five most eminent European languages

Dictionarium quinque nobilissimarum Europae linguarum : Latinae, Italicae, Germanicae, Dalmatiae [!] et Ungaricae ; Vocabula Dalmatica quae Ungari sibi usurparunt ; Institutio christiana ; Symbolum apostolorum
europeana:record.dc:creator: Vrančić, Faust
europeana:record.dc:subject: 400 Language
europeana:record.dc:description: The first Croatian, independently printed dictionary of the five most prominent European languages of the time: Latin, Italian, Croatian, German and Hungarian. Compiled by Faust Vrančić ( 1551–1617) of Šibenik, and printed in Venice in 1595, the dictionary comprises 132 pages and 5,800 Croatian words, mostly in Chakavian, with some Shtokavian dialect. The dictionary is a combination of Vrančić's Latin-Italian-German dictionary and his later 'Vocabula dalmatica quae Ungari sibi usurparunt' (Dalmatian words assimilated by the Hungarians), i.e. the Croatian-Hungarian dictionary. The dictionary proved instrumental in introducing the Croatian language to Europe. It was later expanded again when a Czech Benedictine, Petar Loderecker, compiled a seven-language dictionary in 1605, using Vrančić's dictionary and adding the Czech and the Polish languages. Vrančić's five-language dictionary, along with Loderecker's seven-language dictionary, had eight editions.

Rječnik pet najuglednijih europskih jezika, latinskoga, talijanskoga, hrvatskoga, njemačkoga i mađarskoga, prvi je hrvatski samostalno tiskani rječnik, a sastavio ga je Šibenčanin Faust Vrančić ( 1551.–1617.) te tiskao u Veneciji 1595. Rječnik ima 132 stranice i oko 5800 hrvatskih riječi, većinom čakavskih, ali i štokavskih. Riječi su složene u pet stupaca, a jezici poredani kao u naslovu djela. Čini se da je Vrančić prvo izradio latinsko-talijansko-njemački rječnik, a poslije, učeći mađarski, napisao Vocabula dalmatica quae Ungari sibi usurparunt (Dalmatinske riječi što su ih Mađari prisvojili), tj. hrvatsko-mađarski rječnik, i onda dva rječnika spojio. Tako se pojavio rječnik koji ponosno stoji na početku bogate hrvatske leksikografije i koji je upoznao Europu s hrvatskim jezikom. Češki benediktinac Petar Loderecker sastavio je 1605. sedmojezični rječnik iskoristivši Vrančićev i dodavši češki i poljski jezik. Vrančićev petojezičnik s Lodereckerovim sedmojezičnikom doživio je osam izdanja.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: An anthology of works
Scladanya izvarsnich pisan razlicich poctovanoga gospodina Hanibala Lucia vlastelina hvarschoga, choye cini stampati v Bnecich, sin gnegov Antoni ...
europeana:record.dc:creator: Lucić, Hanibal
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: A native of the island of Hvar, Hanibal Lucić (1485–1553) left a significant body of work. His illegitimate son Antun published almost the entire oeuvre in Venice, three years after the poet's death, under the title 'Scladanya izvarsnich pisan razlicih'. The anthology comprises 22 love poems, the play 'Robinja', several odes, two epitaphs and a translation of Ovid's 'Heroides 16' and the ode 'Pariž Eleni' (Paris to Helen). His play, 'Robinja', is one the first secular Croatian plays and concerns the capture of the daughter of Count Vlasko and her saviour Banus Derenčin. Also included in the anthology is the love poem 'Jur ni jedna na svit vila', considered by scholars to be one of the most beautiful poems in the Croatian language.

Hvaranin Hanibal Lucić (1485.–1553.) ostavio je nevelik, ali značajan opus. Njegov izvanbračni sin Antun objavio je gotovo cijeli taj opus u Veneciji, tri godine nakon pjesnikove smrti pod naslovom Skladanja izvarsnih pisan razlicih. Riječ je o antologiji u kojoj se nalaze 22 ljubavne pjesme, drama Robinja, nekoliko pjesničkih poslanica, dva epitafa i prijevod Ovidijeve heroide Pariž Eleni. Među ljubavnim je pjesmama i Jur ni jedna na svit vila, koju stručnjaci drže jednom od najljepših pjesama u cjelokupnom hrvatskom pjesništvu. Drama Robinja jedna je od prvih hrvatskih drama sa svjetovnom tematikom, s veoma vrijednim lirskim sekvencijama i jednostavnom fabulom koja govori o zarobljenoj kćeri kneza Vlaska i njezinu osloboditelju banu Derenčinu.
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Constitution
Уложение
europeana:record.dc:subject: 340 Law
europeana:record.dc:description: The first Russian statute book to be published typographically, the 'Muscovite Law Code' of 1649 is one of the milestones of Russian history. Many regulatory books and petitions were used as sources for drawing up the Code, which applied a firm grounding to the Russian state. The issues on the state, property and penal laws alone cover 25 chapters and over 900 articles. Affirmed by the Assembly of the Land, it was put into print in 1649 with a circulation of around 1200 copies. But it was soon re-published due to greater demand and distributed around the country.

Соборное уложение царя Алексея Михайловича 1648–1649 гг. – кодекс законов русского государства, принятый Земским собором 1648–1649 гг. Уложение 1649 г. – первый русский свод законов, изданный типографским способом. Уложение составляла специальная комиссия, собранная по указу царя Алексея Михайловича, церковного собора и думы. В комиссию входили два боярина (Н.И. Одоевский и Ф.Ф. Волконский) и два дьяка (Г. Леонтьев и Ф. Грибоедов). Источниками для Соборного уложения 1649 г. послужили Судебник 1550 г. Ивана IV, указные книги Поместного и Земского, Разбойного и других приказов, коллективные челобитные московских и провинциальных дворян, посадских людей, а также Кормчая книга, Литовский статут 1588 г. Всего Соборное уложение включало 25 глав и 967 статей, в которых освещались вопросы государственного, «вещного» и уголовного права. Для утверждения важного государственного документа был созван Земский собор. С 3 октября 1648 г. обсуждение проекта велось параллельно царем с освященным собором и думой и выборными людьми под председательством боярина Ю.А. Долгорукого. К 29 января 1649 г. составление Соборного уложения было завершено. Печатание Уложения было начато 7 апреля и закончено 20 мая 1649 г. Тираж 1200 экземпляров быстро разошелся и в том же 1649-м году были изготовлены ещё 2 новых издания по 1200 экземпляров каждое. Принятие Соборного уложения явилось важной вехой в развитии российской государственности.

europeana:record.dc:title: Mozart auf der Reise nach Prag
europeana:record.dc:creator: Mörike, Eduard
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Lullaby
იავნანამ რა ჰქმნა?
europeana:record.dc:creator: Gogebashvili, Iakob
europeana:record.dc:description: Iakob Gogebashvili (October 15, 1840 – June 1, 1912) was a Georgian educator, children’s writer and journalist, considered to be the founder of the scientific pedagogy in Georgia. Through his masterly compiled children's primer, Mother Tongue (Deda Ena), which in a modified form serves to this day as a manual in Georgian schools, every Georgian since 1880 has learnt to read and write in their native language. The Lullaby is a lyrical story of love for Motherland and the power of the mother tongue.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: My Adventure
ჩემი თავგადასავალი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Tsereteli, Akaki
europeana:record.dc:description: Akaki Tsereteli was a Georgian writer, public figure and benefactor, one of the leaders of national movement in the late 19th century. Tsereteli was born into a prominent noble family in Imereti and was related to King Solomon I of Imereti. Educated at Kutaisi Gymnasium, he continued his studies in St. Petersburg University in 1859-1863. Tsereteli started writing poems early on and, returning to Georgia, he began publishing his poetry and prose as well as publicist works. He joined forces with Ilia Chavchavadze and campaigned against the older generation of Georgian nobles that refused to accept changes. He sought to revive the Georgian culture and language and published a series of articles in the magazine Tsiskari. He co-founded the Society for the Advancement of Learning Among Georgians and the Georgian Drama Society and played an important role in the development of Georgian journalism. He established and edited several popular magazines, including Akakis tviuri krebuli and Khumara. By the 1900s, Tsereteli, together with Ilia Chavchavadze, had become one of the most important leaders of the national movement, known simply as Akaki, and was crucial in reviving the Georgian national consciousness. My Adventure is his autobiographical novel.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Complete Works by Guram Rcheulishvili, Vol. 3
თხზულებათა სრული კრებული ტომი III
europeana:record.dc:creator: Rcheulishvili, Guram
europeana:record.dc:description: Guram Rcheulishvili's first stories brought him a big success. In writer’s life, only few of his works were published. His collected works “Salamura” were published after his death, in 1961. Rcheulishvili’s prose attracted readers by its style, dialogues and ideas. At the age of 26, he died in Gagra on 23 August 1960, when saving an unknown Russian girl in a rough sea.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Complete Works by Guram Rcheulishvili, Vol. 4
თხზულებათა სრული კრებული ტომი IV
europeana:record.dc:creator: Rcheulishvili, Guram
europeana:record.dc:description: Guram Rcheulishvili's first stories brought him a big success. In writer’s life, only few of his works were published. At the age of 26, he died in Gagra on 23 August 1960, when saving an unknown Russian girl in a rough sea.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: The Woman with Headscarf
თავსაფრიანი დედაკაცი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Lortkipanidze, Niko
europeana:record.dc:description: Niko Lortkipanidze (1880-1944) was a Georgian writer. His works had deep social resonances. From his first stories Lordkipanidze proved himself a writer grappling with the basic problems of history and contemporary life. Lordkipanidze’s works are classics of Georgian literature and had a great influence on the development of Soviet Georgian literature and its language. The Woman with Headscarf is an inspiring hymn of human beauty, and virtue.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: New Testament
ახალი აღთქუმაჲ
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Appeal of Stones
ქვათა ღაღადი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Chavchavadze, Ilia
europeana:record.dc:description: One of the most famous critical and polemical works by Ilia Chavchavadze, a Georgian writer, poet, journalist and lawyer who spearheaded the revival of the Georgian national movement in the second half of the 19th century, during the Russian rule of Georgia.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: The Idiot, parts 1 and 2
Идиот, ч. 1 и 2
europeana:record.dc:creator: Достоевский, Федор Михайлович.
europeana:record.dc:subject: 890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: The Idiot' by celebrated Russian author Fyodor Dostoyevsky, is ranked as one of the classic literary achievements of Russia's "Golden Age". It was first published serially in Russky Vestnik between 1868 and 1869. However, it wasn't until the 20th century that it was finally translated in to English.

"Идиот" - роман Ф. М. Достоевского, написанный в XIX столетиию Впервые был опубликован в "Русском вестнике" между 1868 и 1869 гг. Среди других романов Достоевского"Идиот" считается жемчужиной русского Золотого века литературы. Впервые был напечатан на английском языке в XX столетии.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Art of the Hungarian Nation
A magyar nép művészete
europeana:record.dc:creator: Malonyay Dezső
europeana:record.dc:subject: Néprajz;390 Customs, etiquette, folklore
europeana:record.dc:description: Dezső Malonyay was not just an expert on research into folk art, but a highly qualified organiser of collection work. It is thanks to this project that for source material in the five volumes of “The Art of the Hungarian Nation” is still unsurpassable. Malonyai and his team of twenty-five artists systematically visited all the regions of contemporary Hungary that they considered important for folk art. As he says in his introduction, “We explore all Hungarian inhabited regions of our homeland: the more significant it is, the more thorough we are. We briefly describe the people living there: depicting and showing the pictures of their church, cemetery, houses, homes, gardens, the people themselves, their garments, utensils and work tools, always trying to find the elements that they instinctively apply to meet their aesthetic needs…” They started the project in Kalotaszeg, continued with Székely (or Sacler) Land, then went on to Transdanubia, the north of Hungary and the Palóc region. Sadly, the Great Hungarian Plain and north-eastern Hungary were not covered partly due to Malonyay’s death and partly because of World War I.

Malonyay Dezső nem a magyar népművészeti kutatásnak, hanem a gyűjtés megszervezésének volt kiválóan képzett szakértője. Ennek a szervezőmunkának köszönhető a forrásértéket tekintve azóta is felülmúlhatatlan A magyar nép művészete című munka, amely híven tükrözi a magyar népi díszítőművészet valaha volt mesés gazdagságát. Malonyai mintegy huszonöt művészből álló munkacsoportjával tervszerűen járta be a korabeli Magyarország népművészetileg jelentősnek tartott tájait. Mint előszavában írja, „Sorra vesszük hazánk magyarlakta részeit, annál tüzesebben, mennél exponáltabb az illető vidék, s röviden ismertetve, jellemezve az ott lakó népet: leírjuk és képekben megmutatjuk templomát, temetőjét, házát, otthonát, kertjét, őt magát, ruhaviseletét, házi- és munkaeszközeit, megkeresve mindezeken azt, amivel ösztönszerűleg is szépérzékét elégíti ki…” Kalotaszeggel kezdték, Székelyfölddel folytatták, majd a Dunántúl és az északi magyarok, a palócok következtek. Az Alföld és Északkelet-Magyarország kimaradt, ehhez mind Malonyay halála mind az I. világháború kimenetele szomorú okot szolgáltatott.

europeana:record.dc:title: On the practice of medicine and anatomy

Opera omnia medico-practica et anatomica. ... accedunt ejsudem Baglivi Canones de medicina solidorum; Dissertatio de progressione Romani terraemotus; De systemate & usu motus solidorum in corpore animato; De vegetatione lapidum & analogismo circulationis
europeana:record.dc:creator: Baglivi, Đuro
europeana:record.dc:subject: 610 Medical sciences and medicine
europeana:record.dc:description: Đuro Baglivi (1668–1707) medical writer and physician, was one of the most eminent authorities on medical science. After starting his education with the Dubrovnik Jesuits, he went on to study medicine in Naples, eventually becoming personal physician to Pope Innocento XII and professor of medicine at the Rome university, La Sapienza. He published 'De Praxi Medica' in Rome in 1696. His second book, 'De fibra Motrice et Morbosa' was published in 1700. Since 1702, his collected works have had 20 editions in Latin, and a number of translations in various European languages. He was a supporter of functional administration of drugs, and anticipated chemotherapy.

Đuro Baglivi (1668.–1707.), medicinski pisac i liječnik, školovanje je započeo u dubrovačkih isusovaca, među kojima mu je učiteljem bio i Ardelio della Bella. Kao daroviti đak poslan je u Italiju. Medicinu je studirao u Napulju i Salernu. Veze s rodnim gradom nikad nije prekinuo. Bavio se liječništvom te radio i razne pokuse na životinjama. Proučavao je anatomiju, posebice istražujući mišiće i moždanu ovojnicu. Postao je liječnik pape Inocenta XII., a zatim profesor medicine na rimskom sveučilištu La Sapienza. U Rimu je 1696. izdao djelo De praxi medica, te postao članom mnogobrojnih europskih akademija. Drugu knjigu De fibra motrice et morbosa objavljuje 1700. Njegova sabrana djela od 1702. izašla su u 20 izdanja na latinskom, a mnogobrojni prijevodi na europskim jezicima. Zalagao se za funkcionalnu uporabu lijekova, predvidio mogućnost kemoterapije. Bio je jedan od najvećih autoriteta medicinske znanosti. Zanimao se i za numizmatiku, pisao o mineralogiji i meteorologiji.
europeana:record.dc:publisher: Lugduni, sumptibus Anisson et Joannis Posuel
europeana:record.dc:source: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu
europeana:record.dc:rights: Nacionalna i sveučilišna knjižnica u Zagrebu

europeana:record.dc:title: Ariadne : The story of a dream. Vol. 3.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Ouida
europeana:record.dc:subject: 820 English & Old English literatures
europeana:record.dc:description: Marie Louise de la Ramée (1839-1908) wrote under the pseudonym of Ouida (from the childhood mispronunciation of her middle-name). Her first novel, ‘Held in Bondage’ appeared in serial form in ‘Bentley’s’ in 1863. ‘Under Two Flags’ (1867), a melodrama about the French Foreign Legion, proved her best-selling novel despite poor characterisation and factual errors. The author drew on her knowledge of Italy for her novel ‘Ariadne’ (1877), an Italian cobbler's account of a duel over his adopted daughter.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Right Hand of the Grand Master
დიდოსტატის კონსტანტინეს მარჯვენა
europeana:record.dc:creator: Gamsakhurdia, Konstantine
europeana:record.dc:description: The magnum opus by the famous Georgian writer Konstantine Gamsakhurdia, the novel The Right Hand of the Grand Master (1939), is set in the 1110s/20s around the legend of the building of the Cathedral of Living Pillar against a broad panorama of 11th-century Georgia.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Collected Works by Ilia Chavchavadze, Vol. 1
თხზულებანი -I ტომი
europeana:record.dc:creator: Chavchavadze, Ilia
europeana:record.dc:description: Prince Ilia Chavchavadze (8 November [O.S. 27 October] 1837 – 12 September [O.S. 30 August] 1907) was a Georgian writer, poet, journalist and lawyer who spearheaded the revival of the Georgian national movement in the second half of the 19th century, during the Russian rule of Georgia. Today he is widely regarded as one of the founding fathers of modern Georgia. In 1987 he was canonized as Saint Ilia the Righteous by the Georgian Orthodox Church. Inspired by the contemporary liberal movements in Europe, as a writer and a public figure, Ilia Chavchavadze directed much of his efforts toward awakening national ideals in Georgians and to the creation of a stable society in his homeland. His most important literary works were: The Hermit, The Ghost, Otaraant Widow, Kako The Robber and Is He Human, This "Man"?. Chavchavadze was fatally wounded by a gang of assassins. His legacy earned him the broad admiration of the Georgian people.
europeana:record.dc:source: The National Parliamentary Library of Georgia

europeana:record.dc:title: Old Hungarian Language Relics 2.
Régi magyar nyelvemlékek 2.
europeana:record.dc:creator: Magyar Tudós Társaság
europeana:record.dc:subject: Nyelvészet;410 Linguistics
europeana:record.dc:description: The General Assembly of the Hungarian Scholars’ Society decided in September 1832 to start publishing the main medieval language relics of the Hungarian language. According to the decision, Gábor Döbrentei was entrusted with issuing “such old and interesting manuscripts in any subject.” This led to the five volumes of the “Old Hungarian Language Relics” from1838 to 1888. The first volume contains one of the most important documents to this day, the “Funeral Oration”, as well as translations of some books of the Old Testament. The second volume contains the prayer book (1513) of Beningna Magyar, Pál Kinizsi’s wife and “miscellaneous old Hungarian documents” from 1342-1599. The third volume comprises the so-called Tatros copy (1466) and some more miscellaneous texts from the decades between 1540 and 1600. The fourth and fifth volumes have our 16th century codices (e.g. Winkler and Jordánszky Codices). Thus the five-volume collection introduces important language relics, authentically documenting the history of the Hungarian language and also giving an insight into the efforts, standards and methods of 19th century Hungarian linguistic science.

A Magyar Tudós Társaság közgyűlése 1832 szeptemberében határozatot hozott, hogy elkezdik nyomtatásban közreadni a magyar nyelv akkor ismert legfontosabb középkori nyelvemlékeit. A határozat értelmében az „illy régi, akármely tárgyú, de nyelvi tekintetből érdekes kéziratok” kiadásával Döbrentei Gábort bízták meg, így jelent meg 1838 és 1888 között a Régi magyar nyelvemlékek öt kötete. Az első kötet tartalmazza a máig legfontosabbak egyikét, a Halotti beszédet és némely ótestamentumi könyvek fordításait; a második kötet Kinizsi Pálné Magyar Benigna imádságos könyvét (1513) és 1342-1599 között keletkezett „vegyes tárgyú régi magyar iratokat”. A harmadik kötetben olvasható az ún. Tatrosi másolat (1466) és ugyancsak vegyes tartalmú iratok szövegei az 1540-1600 közötti évtizedekből. A negyedik és ötödik kötetben XVI. századi között kódexeink (pl. Winkler-, Jordánszky-kódex) találhatók. Az ötkötetes szöveggyűjteményből egyfelől megismerhetők a magyar nyelv történetét hiteles dokumentáló fontos nyelvemlékek, másfelől fölmérhető, milyen törekvések mentén, milyen színvonalon, milyen tudományos metódussal dolgozott a XIX. század magyar nyelvtudománya, nyelvtörténete.

Первоје ученије книг хотјашчим учитисја книг писмени славенскими називајемоје буквар

europeana:record.dc:title: Swiss paintings, or a picturesque voyage in the Thirteen Cantons Vol. 3

Tableaux de la Suisse, ou voyage pittoresque fait dans les treize cantons et Etats alliés du Corps helvétique : représentant les divers phénomènes que la nature y rassemble, & les beautés dont l'art les a enrichis, suivis de la description topographique, physique, historique, morale, politique & littéraire de ce pays
europeana:record.dc:creator: Née, François Denis
europeana:record.dc:subject: Europe

A separate accompanying volume provides travel descriptions

Les Tableaux de la Suisse offrent une extraordinaire collection de 426 planches gravées en taille-douce par de nombreux artistes dont Le Barbier, Pérignon...: portraits, cartes, scènes historiques, vues de villes et costumes. Des descriptions de voyages accompagnent les images dans un volume séparé

Die Tableaux de la Suisse stellen eine aussergewöhnliche Sammlung von 426 Kupferstichen verschiedener Künstler dar, darunter Le Barbier und Pérignon: Portraits, Karten, historische Ereignisse, Ansichten von Städten, Kostüme. Ein eigener Band enthält ergänzende Bilder zu den Reisebeschreibungen

Lienhard und Gertrud : ein Buch für das Volk Vol. 2

Dieser Bauernroman des Reformpädagogen Pestalozzi handelt von dörflicher Korruption und der Möglichkeit ihrer Beseitigung durch eine aufgeklärte Obrigkeit. Das Werk war ein europaweiter Erfolg

europeana:record.dc:title: Scherz, Satire, Ironie und tiefere Bedeutung!
europeana:record.dc:creator: Grabbe, Christian Dietrich
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.

europeana:record.dc:creator: Heine, Heinrich

europeana:record.dc:creator: Spyri, Johanna
europeana:record.dc:subject: German fiction

europeana:record.dc:title: Here begins the book known as declaration of musical instruments ...
Comiença el libro llamado declaraciõ de instrum~etos musicales ...
europeana:record.dc:creator: Bermudo, Juan, Fray (ca. 1510-ca. 1565)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Música
europeana:record.dc:description: This first edition is a summary (Book one) of what were supposed to be four separate books. One year later he published his book Arte tripharia; the term "tripharia" makes reference to the division of musical instruments, which Bermudo classifies into three groups: "Natural" (human voice), "artificial" ("touch" or string instruments) and "intermediate" (wind" instruments, including the organ). This edition includes a series of original compositions with the didactical purpose of teaching the usual composition techniques of the era. These combine many of the treatises from the previous editions. In the colophon he notes that this work contains "12 new things", appearing firstly a vihuela with seven double-strings and new tuning.

Esta primera edición es un resumen (Libro primero) de lo que pretendían ser cuatro libros separados. Un año más tarde publica su libro Arte tripharia; el término «tripharia» se refiere a la división de los instrumentos de música, que Bermudo clasifica en tres grupos: el «natural» (voz humana), el «artificial» (instrumentos de «toque» o de cuerdas) y el «intermedio» (instrumentos de «ayre», incluso el órgano). En esta edición se incluyen una serie de composiciones originales con el fin didáctico de enseñar las técnicas de composición habituales en su época. En ellos combina muchos de los tratados de las ediciones anteriores En el colofón advierte que esta obra contiene «12 cosas nuevas», figurando, en primer lugar, una vihuela de siete órdenes con temple nuevo.

europeana:record.dc:title: Reineke Fuchs
europeana:record.dc:creator: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von

europeana:record.dc:title: The Description of Székely Land
A Székelyföld leírása
europeana:record.dc:creator: Orbán Balázs (﻿1829-1890)
europeana:record.dc:subject: Történelem;940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: Coming from a traditional Székely family, Balázs Orbán had a rather adventurous youth due to the twists and turns of fate and history. Between the ages of 16 and 30 he travelled widely in Turkey, Greece, the Middle East and England. The long years of homelessness must have played a role in his devoting the rest of his life to local history research. From the 1860s he set himself the aim of roaming the whole of Székely Land. In order to give a comprehensive description of his home country, he supplemented his first hand experience with thorough archival research. “The Description of Székely Land” gives an introduction to the five Székely regions and Burzenland, the region around Brassov. His book describes 520 villages with their ruined castles, temples, natural and archaeological treasures. He does not forget either about the people in the land, their habits, costumes, dances and family life. His undertaking has saved a large amount of already vanished values, while his encyclopaedic wealth is indicated by the fact that scholars in various disciplines, including ethnography, geography, art history and linguistics still find his work highly useful.

Orbán Balázsnak ősi székely család sarjaként a sors és a történelem szeszélyéből kalandos ifjúság jutott. Egy konstantinápolyi örökség reményében tett utazás, később a szabadságharc bukása kikényszerítette emigráció idején 16 és 30 éves kora között bejárta Törökországot, Görögországot, a Közel-Keletet, majd Angliát. Talán a hontalanság hosszú éveinek is szerepe volt abban, hogy életét ezután honismereti munkásságának szentelte. Az 1860-as évektől élete fő céljává a Székelyföld bejárása vált. A tapasztalati anyagot komoly levéltári kutatásokkal egészítette ki, hogy minél átfogóbb leírását adhassa pátriájának. A “Székelyföld leírása” az öt székely szék és a Barcaság területét mutatja be. Könyvében 520 falut és várost ismertet a hozzájuk tartozó várromokkal, templomokkal, természeti, régészeti kincsekkel. Nem feledkezik meg a tájban élő emberek szokásairól, viseletéről, foglalkozásairól, táncairól, családi életéről sem. Munkája rengeteg, azóta eltűnt értéket mentett meg a feledéstől, enciklopédikus gazdagságát pedig jól jellemzi, hogy a legkülönbözőbb tudományok, mint pl. a néprajz, a földrajz, a művészettörténet vagy a nyelvészet kutatói ma is haszonnal tudják forgatni.

europeana:record.dc:title: The Crimson Coach ; Autumn Voyages on the Crimson Coach
A vörös postakocsi ; Őszi utazások a vörös postakocsin
europeana:record.dc:creator: Krúdy Gyula
europeana:record.dc:subject: Magyar irodalom;890 Literatures of other languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Krúdy's The Crimson Coach, published in 1914, became his first bestseller. Its success was nearly unparalleled: in 8 months the novel had 3 editions. According to the memories of contemporaries, all women read it, including those in girls' schools. It is a series of brilliant pieces of short stories and 'poems' expressed in prose, only unified by the protagonist and the peculiar atmosphere. Dream and reality, past and present are intermingled in Krúdy's depiction as well as in the consciousness of his heroes. The novel and its sequel, the Autumn Voyages on the Crimson Coach (1917) evoke the world of turn-of-the-century Pest, illustrated through the relationship between man and woman. The writer creates a peculiar, opaque world blurring dreams and everyday reality, in which nostalgia for his youth and disillusionment with high life and with the conquered women mingles in a sensuous description of environment, objects and persons.

Krúdy Gyula számára az igazi közönségsikert az 1914-ben megjelent A vörös postakocsi című regénye hozta meg. Sikere szinte példátlan volt: nyolc hónap alatt három kiadást ért meg; "minden nő olvasta, még a leányiskolák is" – a kortársak emlékezése szerint. A vörös postakocsi az első sajátos Krúdy-regény, csillogó novelladarabok, prózába fogott költemények sorozata, regénnyé a főhős személye s a hangulat kapcsolja a fejezeteket. Álom és valóság egybemosódik, a jelen és múlt is, a valós személyekről mintázott hősök tudatában csakúgy, mint az ábrázolásban. A regény és folytatása, az 1917-es Őszi utazások a vörös postakocsin a századforduló Pestjének világát elevenítik meg, méghozzá a férfi és nő kapcsolatán keresztül ábrázolva azt. Az író különös, az álmot és a köznapi valóságot sejtelmesen összemosó világot teremt, amelyben az ifjúság iránti nosztalgia és a nagyvilági életből, a meghódított nőkből való kiábrándulás keveredik, s mindez Krúdynak a környezetet, személyeket, tárgyakat érzékletesen megjelenítő, sajátos stílusában.

europeana:record.dc:title: Count Samuel Teleki’s Expedition in Equatorial East Africa in 1887-1888
Teleki Sámuel gróf felfedező útja Kelet-Afrika egyenlítői vidékein 1887-1888-ban
europeana:record.dc:creator: Höhnel Lajos
europeana:record.dc:subject: Utazási irodalom;910 Geography and travel
europeana:record.dc:description: Count Sámuel Teleki came from a prominent family of Transylvanian aristocrats. He went to university in Berlin and Gottingen, where he studied geology, mineralogy, geography and astrology from the best scientists of the age. As a member of parliament, he met and made friends with Prince Rudolph, the heir to the throne of Austria-Hungary, with whom he shared not only a passion for hunting but also a keen interest in politics and science. Probably the idea of combining a planned hunting trip to East Africa with an exploration of unknown lands was suggested by Rudolph, who recommended that Teleki’s companion should be Ludwig von Höhnel, an Austrian naval officer, who was familiar with sciences and proved to be an excellent cartographer. The great enterprise, the costs of which were covered from Teleki’s private assets, lasted from 1886 to 1889. Their expedition of some three thousand kilometres starting at Lake Baringo in Kenya passed through lands. During their trip, they met unknown people and landscapes and made a number of geographical, geological, zoological and botanical discoveries. The almost complete climbing of the 5895 meter high Mount Kilimanjaro (Teleki reached 5310 meters, setting up a record at the time), the discovery of Lake Rudolph and Lake Stefanie and the Teleki Volcano (this is probably the only Hungarian name featuring on the map of Africa) and the description of the Naivasha Groove.

Gróf Teleki Sámuel régi erdélyi arisztokrata család sarja. Berlinben és Göttingenben végezte egyetemi tanulmányait, ahol kora nagyhírű tudósai többek közt geológiára, ásványtanra, földrajzra, csillagászatra is oktatták. Országgyűlési képviselőként ismerkedett meg Rudolf trónörökössel, akivel nem csak vadász-szenvedélyük, de politikai és természettudományos érdeklődésük rokonsága is szoros barátságot eredményezett. Valószínűleg Rudolf sugallta az ötletet, hogy Teleki tervezett kelet-afrikai vadászútját ismeretlen vidékek felkutatásával is összekösse. Útitársnak a pozsonyi születésű osztrák Ludwig von Höhnel sorhajóhadnagyot ajánlotta, aki járatos volt a természettudományokban és kiváló térképésznek bizonyult. A hatalmas vállalkozás, amelynek költségeit Teleki magánvagyonából fedezte, 1886-tól 1889-ig tartott. 3000 km hosszú expedíciójuk a kenyai Baringó-tótól északra haladt át. Sok kalanddal és viszontagsággal tarkított útjuk során ismeretlen népekkel, természeti tájakkal találkoztak, földrajzi, geológiai, állattani, növénytani felfedezéseket tettek. Külön kiemelendő az 5895 méteres Kilimanjaro majdnem sikeres megmászása ((Teleki 5310 m magasra jutott fel, a maga idejében rekord), a Rudolf- és Stefánia-tavak valamint a Teleki-vulkán (a mai Afrika térképén valószínűleg az egyedüli magyar név) felfedezése, a kelet-afrikai árokrendszerhez tartozó Najvasa árok leírása.

europeana:record.dc:title: Count Ferenc Széchényi
Gróf Széchényi Ferenc
europeana:record.dc:creator: Fraknói Vilmos
europeana:record.dc:subject: Történelem;940 General history of Europe
europeana:record.dc:description: In the “Hungarian Historical Biographies” series, biographies of prominent personalities in Hungarian history were introduced by outstanding historians and politicians of the age. The series of monographs was published by the Hungarian History Association, launched in 1885 by the editor Sándor Szilágyi. Vilmos Fraknói (Frankl) was a conservative clerical historiographer dealing with medieval, ecclesiastical and diplomatic history. He was the editor of a number of series of publications, among them the “Treatises about Historical Sciences” (between 1872 and 1878) and the first ten volumes of the “Hungarian Parliamentary Memories” (Monumenta comitialia regni Hungariae). In 1875-1879 he was the guardian of the Hungarian National Museum. A politician and founder of the National Library, Count Ferenc Széchényi was Count István Széchenyi’s father. Donating on 25th November 1802 his collection of some thirteen thousand books and over 1200 manuscripts, maps, crests and cuts to the Hungarian nation, he thus established the Hungarian national library under the name of Bibliotheca Regnicolaris. According to Act 1808/VIII, the institution continued its activity under the name of National Széchényi Library within the newly established Hungarian National Museum.

A Magyar Történeti Életrajzok sorozatban, a magyar történelemben jeles szerepet játszó személyiségek életrajzait a kor kiváló történészei, politikusai mutatták be. A monográfia-sorozat a Magyar Történelmi Társulat kiadványa volt, amit 1885-ben Szilágyi Sándor szerkesztésével indítottak el. Fraknói (Frankl) Vilmos konzervatív-klerikális történetíró volt, a középkori történelemmel, egyház- és diplomáciatörténettel foglalkozott. Számos kiadványsorozatot szerkesztett, többek között az Értekezések a történeti tudományok köréből sorozatot (1872-1878 között), és a Magyar Országgyűlési Emlékek (Monumenta comitialia regni Hungariae) első 10 kötetét. 1875-1879 között a Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum könyvtárának őre lett. Gróf Széchényi Ferenc politikus, a Nemzeti Könyvtár megalapítója, Gróf Széchenyi István apja volt. 1802. november 25-én, kb. 13.000 nyomtatott könyvből, 1200-nál több kéziratból, térképből, címerekből, metszetekből álló gyűjteményét a magyar nemzetnek ajándékozta, és ezzel Bibliotheca Regnicolaris néven megalapította a magyar nemzeti könyvtárat. Az intézmény az 1808/VIII-as törvénycikk értelmében az újonnan létrehozott Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum keretén belül működött tovább, a Magyar Nemzeti Múzeum Országos Széchényi Könyvtára néven.

europeana:record.dc:title: Faust
europeana:record.dc:creator: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von
europeana:record.dc:subject: 830 Literatures of Germanic languages
europeana:record.dc:description: Germany is contributing digitised versions of well-known literary works by German authors from different centuries to "Reading Europe". The printed editions of these titles, taken from the stocks of the German National Library, were digitised. The brief of the library is to collect Germany's published cultural and scientific heritage since 1913, to preserve it for posterity and to make it accessible for use. The German National Library therefore documents the intellectual and literary output of the German-speaking countries. Subject librarians from the library made the selections for "Reading Europe", choosing exclusively volumes which are no longer subject to copyright.

Deutschlands Beitrag zu "Reading Europe" sind die Digitalisate von bekannten literarischen Werken deutscher Autoren aus allen Jahrhunderten. Digitalisiert wurden die Druckausgaben dieser Titel aus dem Bestand der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek, die das kulturelle und wissenschaftliche Erbe Deutschlands in seiner ab 1913 veröffentlichten Form sammelt, es für immer bewahrt und für die Nutzung zugänglich macht. Die Deutsche Nationalbibliothek dokumentiert damit das geistige und literarische Schaffen im deutschen Sprachraum. Die Auswahl für "Reading Europe" trafen Fachreferentinnen und Fachreferenten der Bibliothek, ausgewählt wurden ausschließlich Bände, die nicht mehr dem Urheberschutz unterliegen.
